Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Roles of Functional, Phylogenetic, and Genetic Diversity in Structuring and Sustaining Plant Communities Through Environmental Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
To understand the origins and dynamics of plant diversity, this project will investigate the evolutionary roots of plant diversity, how plant traits diversified, and how evolutionary history and traits now affect the ability of plants to persist in landscapes subject to climate change, disturbance, and habitat fragmentation. The project focuses on Wisconsin where remarkably detailed data exist on plant distributions and abundances and how these have changed over the past 50+ years. Gene sequences will be used to reconstruct evolutionary relationships. Plant traits will be mapped onto these trees to infer when they evolved, how they changed, and how ancestry and traits affect species success and co-occurrences. Analyses of genome size and genetic variation in some species will show how patterns of local and regional variation relate to dispersal traits, geographic range, habitat fragmentation, and landscape dynamics. Data on historical community changes and climate projections will be used to predict future changes in range and abundance. This project will thus integrate our understanding of how plant traits evolve, how traits relate to ecological success, and how traits interact with phylogeny, genome size, and landscape conditions to affect species persistence and invasions.

Plant diversity underlies ecosystem productivity and diversity, yet we still lack a clear picture of why most habitats are losing species while weedy plants are invading. This project will illuminate the mechanisms driving these changes and so improve our ability to manage natural and constructed ecosystems wisely. The trait and sequence data will also enhance national databases, facilitating further research. The project will contribute substantially to human resources by training cadres of undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral researchers in a broad set of skills related to biodiversity science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant diversity sustains all animal life on Earth including our own.  We undertook this project in order to understand better the forces that generate, maintain, and threaten ecological, evolutionary, and genetic diversity in the plants that occur in one state – Wisconsin.  We sought to understand how this diversity is manifest in the diversity of plant forms and functions, the phylogenetic relationships that exist among these species, the geographic distribution of this diversity, and how genetic variation is distributed within and among populations in the forests and grasslands of Wisconsin.  In particular, our goal was to understand how plant species and communities respond to the forces driving ecological change, including habitat loss and fragmentation, invasive species, over-abundant deer, aerial nitrogen deposition, and climate change.  This, in turn, would help us to understand which species and communities are most vulnerable, or resistant, to these drivers of change and thus how they are likely to respond in the future.  

In our work, we explored several questions such as how genomes vary in size among species and how plants in one state are related to each other.  To accurately infer relationships, we genetically “bar-coded” >2500 plant species, making Wisconsin the first state with all its species identified in this way.  We also measured how species vary in a broad set of plant leaf, stem, and reproductive traits and how this variation affects the sorting of plant species into communities and their shifts in distribution and abundance over the past 50-60 years.  We are also studying how much these traits reflect phylogenetic similarity (how close two species are on the tree of life).  We are examining how plant functional traits reflect phylogenetic history and patterns of diversification, on the one hand, and the effects these traits have on patterns of community assembly and change on the other.  That is, we use phylogenetic methods to explore the separate and combined effects of phylogeny and traits on ecological processes.  To better understand how plant species come to differentiate from each other and coexist, we studied gene flow and how genetic diversity is distributed within and among populations.  This also helps us understand genetic factors that may threaten the ability of some populations to persist.  Finally, we are using the detailed patterns of ecological change over the past 50-60 years to understand how that factors driving ecological change may combine and interact.

We documented many aspects of ecological change in Wisconsin including the fact that most sites have declined in plant diversity over the past 50-60 years, sites are mostly converging in composition, and that invasive species have become far more important.  These trends are all greater in smaller patches of habitat and in more fragmented landscapes surrounded by more roads, houses, and agriculture.  Species have also shifted appreciably in their geographic distributions over this period, generally moving to the Northwest in a pattern that mirrors the shifts in climate that these species have experienced.  Their movements, however, generally lag behind the amount of climate change that has occurred.  Leaf nitrogen levels within plant communities have come to reflect the amount of nitrogen deposition occurring at each site with exotic species showing particularly high leaf nitrogen levels.  This suggests that nitrogen pollution may be accelerating invasions of exotic species.  We also discovered that the distribution and abundance of species over sites in the 1950s within a given community type (like upland forests in northern Wisconsin) can be used in a simple model to predict changes in those abundances 50 years later.  The trait data may allow us to improve these predictions and to compare our results with those from other temperate regions around the world. 

By better understanding the forces acting on ecosystems and how big the threats are to sustaining plant genetic, species, and trait diversity, we can learn how better to sustain biological diversity and the many ecological services it supports.  Results from our research will also help us to learn how better to manage the forests, grasslands, and wildlife we oversee so as to sustain their economic productivity and ecological resilience.  In addition, our project trained many scientists and resulted in a body of scientific work that will stimulate further interest and research into the forces that affect all ecosystems.
